en.title: Mighty Chin-Chin What's the Matter
en.drag_instruction_classify: Drag and drop the object into the matching group.
en.drag_instruction_play: Drag and drop the object to the highlighted area.
en.palette_switch_instruction: Click on the group tab to switch to another group.
en.play_instruction: Press this button to let the mighty Chin-Chin move.
en.stop_instruction: Press this button to go back to placing objects.
en.reset_instruction: Press and hold this button to clear out all the objects.
en.level01_intro_1: In order to help the mighty Chin-Chin, we will need to learn how to use a bunch of objects with special properties.
en.level01_intro_2: By learning the properties of objects, we can use them effectively in many situations.
en.level01_property_1: An object has many different properties.
en.level01_property_2: Each property of an object tells us its quality and attribute.
en.level01_property_3: For example, we can say that a rubber duck is: lightweight, can float above water, and can block electricity.
en.level01_classify_1: Classify means to put objects into groups because of their shared properties.
en.level01_classify_2: This allows us to make use of objects without having to guess which is which at any situation!
en.level01_shape_size_1: An object can be made into different shapes and sizes.
en.level01_shape_size_2: For example, a soft material like clay can be squeezed to become tall, or wide.
en.level01_begin_1: Let's go ahead and shape a bunch of clay!
en.level01_begin_2: You will be tasked to place them into these groups: tall and wide.
en.level01_play_begin_1: Look! There's one of the star fragments.
en.level01_play_begin_2: Let's go ahead and help the mighty Chin-Chin cross the chasm!
en.level02_intro_1: For this part, we will be looking at the weight property of objects.
en.level02_intro_2: The weight of an object tells us how light or heavy it is.
en.level02_intro_3: One way to determine an object's weight is by using a balance scale.
en.level02_light_1: On this example, we can say a 2 pounds pillow is a lightweight relative to a 20 pounds block.
en.level02_heavy_1: A 40 pounds iron block would be a heavyweight relative to a 20 pounds block.
en.level02_begin_1: Now let's sort out some objects into two classification: light and heavy!
en.level02_begin_2: Remember that an object is light if the left scale goes up, and heavy if the left scale goes down.
en.level03_intro_1: Now we will be looking at an object's property called buoyancy.
en.level03_buoyancy_1: An object's buoyancy determines wether it moves upwards or downwards in liquid matter, such as water.
en.level03_buoyancy_2: If an object moves upward in water, it floats.
en.level03_buoyancy_3: If an object moves downward in water, it sinks.
en.level03_begin_1: Let's go ahead and sort these objects on wether they float or sink!
en.level04_intro_1: For this final part, we will be looking at the conductive property of objects.
en.level04_intro_2: An object's conductivity determines if it can transmit heat, electricity, or sound.
en.level04_conductive_1: Here we see that an iron block is highly conductive with electricity.
en.level04_non_conductive_1: As for a granite rock, not so much.
en.level04_begin_1: Now let's go ahead and sort these objects on wether they are electrically conductive or not!
en.level04_begin_2: If enough electricity conducts through an object, the light bulb should shine brightly.
